was the warmth of her expreſſions!—I was aſhamed to appear leſs happy—though I had come reſolved to wear a face of coolneſs and upbraiding. Sir Anthony's preſence prevented my propoſed expoſtulations:—yet I muſt be ſatisfied that ſhe has not been ſo very happy in my abſence.—She is coming!—Yes!—I know the nimbleneſs of her tread, when ſhe thinks her impatient Faulkland counts the moments of her ſtay.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I had not hop'd to ſee you again ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Could I, Julia, be contented with my firſt welcome—reſtrained as we were by the preſence of a third perſon?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: O Faulkland, when your kindneſs can make me thus happy, let me not think that I diſcovered more coolneſs in your firſt ſalutation than my long-hoarded joy could have preſaged.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: 'Twas but your fancy, Julia.—I was rejoiced to ſee you—to ſee you in ſuch health—Sure I had no cauſe for coldneſs?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay then, I ſee you have taken ſomething ill.—You muſt not conceal from me what it is.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Well then—ſhall I own to you—but you will deſpiſe me, Julia—nay, I deſpiſe myſelf for it.—Yet I will own, that my joy at hearing of your health and arrival here, by your neighbour Acres, was ſomething damped, by his dwelling much on the high ſpirits you had enjoyed in Devonſhire—on your mirth—your ſinging—dancing, and I know not what!—For ſuch is my temper, Julia, that I ſhould regard every mirthful moment in your abſence as a treaſon to conſtancy: —The mutual tear that ſteals down the cheek of parting lovers is a compact, that no ſmile ſhall live there till they meet again.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Muſt I never ceaſe to tax my Faulkland with this teaſing minute caprice?—Can the idle reports of a ſilly boor weigh in your breaſt againſt my tried affection?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: They have no weight with me, Julia: no, no—I am happy if you have been ſo—yet only ſay, that you did not ſing with mirth—ſay that you thought of Faulkland in the dance.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I never can be happy, in your abſence.— If I wear a countenance of content, it is to ſhew that my mind holds no doubt of my Faulkland's truth.—If I ſeem'd ſad—it were to make malice triumph; and ſay, that I had fixed my heart on one, who left me to lament his roving, and my own credulity.—Believe me, Faulkland, I mean not to upbraid you, when I ſay, that I have often dreſſed ſorrow in ſmiles, leſt my friends ſhould gueſs whoſe unkindneſs had cauſed my tears.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: You were ever all goodneſs to me.—O, I am a brute, when I but admit a doubt of your true conſtancy!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If ever, without ſuch cauſe from you, as I will not ſuppoſe poſſible, you find my affections veering but a point, may I become a proverbial ſcoff for levity, and baſe ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ah! Julia, that laſt word is grating to me. I would I had no title to your gratitude! Search your heart, Julia; perhaps what you have miſtaken for Love, is but the warm effuſion of a too thankful heart!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: For what quality muſt I love you?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: For no quality! To regard me for any quality of mind or underſtanding, were only to eſteem me. And for perſon—I have often wiſh'd myſelf deformed, to be convinced that I owed no obligation there for any part of your affection.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
Where Nature has beſtowed a ſhew of nice attention in the features of a man, he ſhould laugh
at it, as miſplaced. I have ſeen men, who in this vain article perhaps might rank above you; but my heart has never aſked my eyes if it were ſo or not.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Now this is not well from you, Julia—I deſpiſe perſon in a man—Yet if you lov'd me as I wiſh, though I were an Aethiop, you'd think none ſo fair.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I ſee you are determined to be unkind.— The contract which my poor father bound us in gives you more than a lover's privilege.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Again, Julia, you raiſe ideas that feed and juſtify my doubts.—I would not have been more free—no—I am proud of my reſtraint.— Yet—yet—perhaps your high reſpect alone for this ſolemn compact has fettered your inclinations, which elſe had made worthier choice.—How ſhall I be ſure, had you remained unbound in thought and promiſe, that I ſhould ſtill have been the object of your perſevering love?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then try me now.—Let us be free as ſtrangers as to what is paſt:—my heart will not feel more liberty!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: There now! ſo haſty, Julia! ſo anxious to be free!—If your love for me were fixed and ardent, you would not looſe your hold, even tho' I wiſh'd it!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: O, you torture me to the heart!—I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p:
I do not mean to diſtreſs you.—If I lov'd you leſs, I ſhould never give you an uneaſy moment.—But hear me.—All my fretful doubts ariſe from this—Women are not uſed to weigh, and ſeparate the motives of their affections:—the cold dictates of prudence, gratitude, or filial duty, may ſometimes be miſtaken for the pleadings of the heart.—I would not boaſt—yet let me ſay, that I have neither age, perſon, or character, to found
diſlike on;—my fortune ſuch as few ladies could be charged with indiſcretion in the match.—O Julia! when Love receives ſuch countenance from Prudence, nice minds will be ſuſpicious of its birth.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I know not whither your inſinuations would tend:—as they ſeem preſſing to inſult me—I will ſpare you the regret of having done ſo.—I have given you no cauſe for this!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: In Tears! ſtay, Julia: ſtay but for a moment.—The door is faſtened!—Julia!— my ſoul—but for one moment:—I hear her ſobbing!—'Sdeath! what a brute am I to uſe her thus! Yet ſtay.—Aye—ſhe is coming now:—how little reſolution there is in woman!—how a few ſoft words can turn them!—No, faith!—ſhe is not coming either.—Why, Julia—my love— ſay but that you forgive me—come but to tell me that—now, this is being too reſentful:—ſtay! ſhe is coming too—I thought ſhe would—no ſteadineſs in any thing! her going away muſt have been a mere trick then—ſhe ſha'n't ſee that I was hurt by it.—I'll affect indifference—(hums a tune: then liſtens)—No—Z—ds! ſhe's not coming!— nor don't intend it, I ſuppoſe.—This is not ſteadineſs, but obſtinacy! Yet I deſerve it.—What, after ſo long an abſence, to quarrel with her tenderneſs! —'twas barbarous and unmanly!—I ſhould be aſhamed to ſee her now.—I'll wait till her juſt reſentment is abated—and when I diſtreſs her ſo again, may I loſe her for ever! and be linked inſtead to ſome antique virago, whoſe knawing paſſions, and long-hoarded ſpleen, ſhall make me curſe my folly half the day, and all the night!

div.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Your being Sir Anthony's ſon, Captain, would itſelf be a ſufficient accommodation;—but from the ingenuity of your appearance, I am convinced you deſerve the character here given of you.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Permit me to ſay, Madam, that as I never yet have had the pleaſure of ſeeing Miſs Languiſh, my principal inducement in this affair at preſent, is the honour of being allied to Mrs. Malaprop; of whoſe intellectual accompliſhments, elegant manners, and unaffected learning, no tongue is ſilent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Sir, you do me infinite honour!— I beg, Captain, you'll be ſeated.—(Sit)—Ah! few gentlemen, now a days, know how to value the ineffectual qualities in a woman! few think how a little knowledge become a gentlewoman! Men have no ſenſe now but for the worthleſs flower, beauty!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: It is but too true indeed, Ma'am;—yet I fear our ladies ſhould ſhare the blame—they think our admiration of beauty ſo great, that knowledge in them would be ſuperfluous. Thus, like gardentrees, they ſeldom ſhew fruits, till time has robb'd them of the more ſpecious bloſſom.—Few, like Mrs. Malaprop and the Orange-tree, are rich in both at once!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p:
Sir—you overpower me with goodbreeding.—He is the very Pine-apple of politeneſs! You are not ignorant, Captain, that this giddy girl has ſomehow contrived to fix her affections on a beggarly, ſtrolling, eve's-dropping Enſign,
whom none of us have ſeen, and nobody knows any thing of.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O, I have heard the ſilly affair before.— I'm not at all prejudiced againſt her on that account.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: You are very good, and very conſiderate, Captain.—I am ſure I have done every thing in my power ſince I exploded the affair! long ago I laid my poſitive conjunction on her never to think on the fellow again;—I have ſince laid Sir Anthony's prepoſition before her;—but I'm ſorry to ſay ſhe ſeems reſolved to decline every particle that I enjoin her.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: It muſt be very diſtreſſing indeed, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: It gives me the hydroſtatics to ſuch a degree!—I thought ſhe had perſiſted from correſponding with him; but behold this very day, I have interceded another letter from the fellow! I believe I have it in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O the devil! my laſt note.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Aye, here it is.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Aye, my note indeed! O the little traitreſs Lucy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: There, perhaps you may know the writing.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: I think I have ſeen the hand before—yes, I certainly muſt have ſeen this hand before:—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Nay, but read it, Captain.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: (Reads) My ſoul's idol, my ador'd Lydia! —Very tender indeed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Tender! aye, and prophane too, o' my conſcience!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: I am exceſſively alarmed at the intelligence you ſend me, the more ſo as my new rival—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: That's you, Sir.
has univerſally the character of being an accompliſhed gentleman, and a man of honour.—Well, that's handſome enough.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O, the fellow had ſome deſign in writing ſo—

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: That he had, I'll anſwer for him, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: But go on, Sir—you'll ſee preſently.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: As for the old weather-beaten ſhe-dragon who guards you,—Who can he mean by that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Me, Sir—me—he means me there— what do you think now?—but go on a little further.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Impudent ſcoundrel!—it ſhall go hard but I will elude her vigilance, as I am told that the ſame ridiculous vanity, which makes her dreſs up her coarſe features, and deck her dull chat with hard words which ſhe don't underſtand—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: There, Sir! an attack upon my language! what do you think of that?—an aſperſion upon my parts of ſpeech! was ever ſuch a brute! ſave if I reprehend any thing in this world, it is the uſe of my oracular tongue, and a nice derangement of epitaphs!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: He deſerves to be hang'd and quartered! let me ſee— ſame ridiculous vanity —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: You need not read it again, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: I beg pardon, Ma'am does alſo lay her open to the groſſeſt deceptions from flattery and pretended admiration—an impudent coxcomb! ſo that I have a ſcheme to ſee you ſhortly with the old Harridan's conſent, and even to make her a go between in our interviews.—Was ever ſuch aſſurance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Did you ever hear any thing like it? —he'll elude my vigilance, will he?—yes, yes! ha! ha! he's very likely to enter theſe floors!— we'll try who can plot beſt!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! had a conceited puppy, ha! ha! ha!—Well, but Mrs. Malaprop, as the girl ſeems ſo infatuated by this fellow, ſuppoſe you were to wink at her correſponding with him for
a little time—let her even plot an elopement with him—then do you connive at her eſcape—while I, juſt in the nick, will have the fellow laid by the heels, and fairly contrive to carry her off in his ſtead.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: I am delighted with the ſcheme, never was any thing better perpetrated!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: But, pray, could not I ſee the lady for a few minutes now?—I ſhould like to try her temper a little.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Why, I don't know—I doubt ſhe is not prepared for a firſt viſit of this kind.— There is a decorum in theſe matters.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O Lord! ſhe won't mind me—only tell her Beverley—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Gently, good tongue.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: What did you ſay of Beverley?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O, I was going to propoſe that you ſhould tell her, by way of jeſt, that it was Beverley who was below—ſhe'd come down faſt enough then—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: 'Twould be a trick ſhe well-deſerves —beſides you know the fellow tells her he'll get my conſent to ſee her—ha! ha!—Let him if he can, I ſay again.—Lydia, come down here!
—He'll make me a go-between in their interviews! —ha! ha! ha! Come down, I ſay, Lydia!—I don't wonder at your laughing, ha! ha! ha! his impudence is truly ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: 'Tis very ridiculous, upon my ſoul, Ma'am, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: The little huſſy won't hear.—Well, I'll go and tell her at once who it is—ſhe ſhall know that Capt. Abſolute is come to wait on her. —And I'll make her behave as becomes a young woman.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: As you pleaſe, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: For the preſent, Captain, your ſervant—Ah! you've not done laughing yet, I ſee— elude my vigilance! yes, yes, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! one would think now that I might throw off all diſguiſe at once, and ſeize my prize with ſecurity—but ſuch is Lydia's caprice, that to undeceive were probably to loſe her. —I'll ſee whether ſhe knows me.

div.stage: [Walks aſide, and ſeems engaged in looking at the pictures.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: What a ſcene am I now to go thro'! ſurely nothing can be more dreadful than to be obliged to liſten to the loathſome addreſſes of a ſtranger to one's heart.—I have heard of girls perſecuted as I am, who have appealed in behalf of their favoured lover to the generoſity of his rival: ſuppoſe I were to try it—there ſtands the hated rival—an officer too!—but O how unlike my Beverley!— I wonder he don't begin—truly he ſeems a very negligent wooer!—quite at his eaſe, upon my word! I'll ſpeak firſt—Mr. Abſolute.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: O Heav'ns! Beverley!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Huſh!—huſh, my life!—ſoftly! be not ſurpriſed!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I am ſo aſtoniſhed! and ſo terrified! and ſo overjoy'd!—for Heav'n's ſake! how came you here?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Briefly—I have deceived your Aunt—I was informed that my new rival was to viſit here this evening, and contriving to have him kept away, have paſſed myſelf on her for Capt. Abſolute.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: O, charming!—And ſhe really takes you for young Abſolute?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O, ſhe's convinced of it.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I can't forbear laughing to think how her ſagacity is over-reached!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: But we trifle with our precious moments— ſuch another opportunity may not occur—then let me now conjure my kind, my condeſcending angel, to fix the time when I may reſcue her from undeſerved perſecution, and with a licenſed warmth plead for my reward.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Will you then, Beverley, conſent to forfeit that portion of my paltry wealth?—that burthen on the wings of love?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O come to me—rich only thus—in lovelineſs—Bring no portion to me but thy love—'twill be generous in you, Lydia—for well you know, it is the only dower your poor Beverley can repay.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: How perſuaſive are his words!—how charming will poverty be with him!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Ah! my ſoul, what a life will we then live? Love ſhall be our idol and ſupport! we will worſhip him with a monaſtic ſtrictneſs; abjuring all worldly toys, to center every thought and action there.—Proud of calamity, we will enjoy the wreck of wealth; while the ſurrounding gloom of adverſity ſhall make the flame of our pure love ſhow doubly bright.—By Heav'ns! I would fling all goods of fortune from me with a prodigal hand to enjoy the ſcene where I might claſp my Lydia to my boſom, and ſay, the world affords no ſmile to me—but here—
If ſhe holds out now the devil is in it!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Now could I fly with him to the Antipodes! but my perſecution is not yet come to a criſis.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: I'm impatient to know how the little huzzy deports herſelf.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: So penſive, Lydia!—is then your warmth abated?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Warmth abated!—ſo!—ſhe has been in a paſſion, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: No—nor ever can while I have life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: An ill-temper'd little devil!—She'll be in a paſſion all her life—will ſhe?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Think not the idle threats of my ridiculous aunt can ever have any weight with me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Very dutiful, upon my word!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Let her choice be Capt. Abſolute, but Beverley is mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed at her aſſurance!— to his face—this to his face!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Thus then let me enforce my ſuit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Aye—poor young man!—down on his knees entreating for pity!—I can contain no longer.—Why, huzzy! huzzy!—I have overheard you.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O confound her vigilance!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Capt. Abſolute—I know not how to apologize for her ſhocking rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: So—all's ſafe, I find.
I have hopes, Madam, that time will bring the young lady—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O, there's nothing to be hoped for from her! ſhe's as headſtrong as an allegory on the banks of Nile.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, what do you charge me with now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Why, thou unbluſhing rebel—didn't you tell this gentleman to his face that you loved another better?—didn't you ſay you never would be his?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: No, Madam—I did not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p:
Good Heav'ns! what aſſurance!— Lydia, Lydia, you ought to know that lying don't
become a young woman!—Didn't you boaſt that Beverley—that ſtroller Beverley, poſſeſſed your heart?—Tell me that, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Ma'am, and none but Beverley—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Hold;—hold Aſſurance!—you ſhall not be ſo rude.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Nay, pray Mrs. Malaprop, don't ſtop the young lady's ſpeech:—ſhe's very welcome to talk thus—it does not hurt me in the leaſt, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: You are too good, Captain—too amiably patient—but come with me, Miſs—let us ſee you again ſoon, Captain—remember what we have fixed.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: I ſhall, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Come, take a graceful leave of the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: May every bleſſing wait on my Beverley, my lov'd Bev—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Huzzy! I'll choak the word in your throat!—come along—come along.

div.stage: [Beverley kiſſing his hand to Lydia—Mrs. Malaprop ſtopping her from ſpeaking.

div.head: SCENE V. Acres's lodgings.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Indeed, David—do you think I become it ſo?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: You are quite another creature, believe me Maſter, by the Maſs! an' we've any luck we ſhall ſee the Devon monkeyrony in all the printſhops in Bath!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Dreſs does make a difference, David.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: 'Tis all in all, I think—difference! why, an' you were to go now to Clod-Hall, I am certain the old lady wouldn't know you: Maſter Butler wouldn't believe his own eyes, and Mrs. Pickle would cry, "Lard preſarve me!" our dairy-maid would come giggling to the door, and I warrant Dolly Teſter, your Honour's favourite, would bluſh like my waiſtcoat.—Oons! I'll hold a gallon, there an't a dog in the houſe but would bark, and I queſtion whether Phillis would wag a hair of her tail!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Aye, David, there's nothing like poliſhing.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: So I ſays of your Honour's boots; but the boy never heeds me!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: But, David, has Mr. De-la-Grace been here? I muſt rub up my balancing, and chaſing, and boring.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I'll call again, Sir.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Do—and ſee if there are any letters for me at the poſt-office.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I will.—By the Maſs, I can't help looking at your head!—if I hadn't been by at the cooking, I wiſh I may die if I ſhould have known the diſh again myſelf!

div.stage: [Acres comes forward, practiſing a dancing ſtep.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p:
Sink, ſlide—coupee—Confound the firſt inventors of cotillons! ſay I—they are as bad as algebra to us country gentlemen—I can walk a Minuet eaſy enough when I'm forced!—and I have been accounted a good ſtick in a Country-dance. —Odd's jigs and tabors!—I never valued your croſsover two couple—figure in—right and left—and I'd foot it with e'er a captain in the county!—but theſe outlandiſh heathen Allemandes and Cotillons are quite beyond me!—I ſhall never proſper at 'em, that's ſure—mine are true-born Engliſh legs— they don't underſtand their curſt French lingo!
—their Pas this, and Pas that, and Pas t'other!— d—n me, my feet don't like to be called Paws! no, 'tis certain I have moſt Antigallican Toes!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Here is Sir Lucius O'Trigger to wait on you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Shew him in.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Mr. Acres, I am delighted to embrace you.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: My dear Sir Lucius, I kiſs your hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pray, my friend, what has brought you ſo ſuddenly to Bath?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Faith! I have followed Cupid's Jack-a-Lantern, and find myſelf in a quagmire at laſt.— In ſhort, I have been very ill-uſed, Sir Lucius.— I don't chooſe to mention names, but look on me as on a very ill-uſed gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pray, what is the caſe?—I aſk no names.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Mark me, Sir Lucius, I falls as deep as need be in love with a young lady—her friends take my part—I follow her to Bath—ſend word of my arrival; and receive anſwer, that the lady is to be otherwiſe diſpoſed of.—This, Sir Lucius, I call being ill-uſed.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Very ill, upon my conſcience—Pray, can you divine the cauſe of it?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Why, there's the matter: ſhe has another lover, one Beverley, who, I am told, is now in Bath. —Odds ſlanders and lies! he muſt be at the bottom of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: A rival in the caſe, is there?—and you think he has ſupplanted you unfairly.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Unfairly!—to be ſure he has.—He never could have done it fairly.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Then ſure you know what is to be done!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Not I, upon my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: We wear no ſwords here, but you underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: What! fight him!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Aye, to be ſure: what can I mean elſe?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: But he has given me no provocation.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Now, I think he has given you the greateſt provocation in the world.—Can a man commit a more heinous offence againſt another than to fall in love with the ſame woman? O, by my ſoul, it is the moſt unpardonable breach of friendſhip!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Breach of friendſhip! Aye, aye; but I have no acquaintance with this man. I never ſaw him in my life.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: That's no argument at all—he has the leſs right then to take ſuch a liberty.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: 'Gad that's true—I grow full of anger, Sir Lucius!—I fire apace! Odds hilts and blades! I find a man may have a deal of valour in him, and not know it! But couldn't I contrive to have a little right of my ſide?

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: What the d—l ſignifies right, when your honour is concerned? Do you think Achilles, or my little Alexander the Great ever inquired where the right lay? No, by my ſoul, they drew their broad-ſwords, and left the lazy ſons of peace to ſettle the juſtice of it.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Your words are a grenadier's march to my heart! I believe courage muſt be catching!— I certainly do feel a kind of valour riſing as it were —a kind of courage, as I may ſay—Odds flints, pans, and triggers! I'll challenge him directly.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p:
Ah, my little friend! if we had Blunderbuſs-Hall here—I could ſhew you a range of anceſtry,
in the O'Trigger line, that would furniſh the new room; every one of whom had killed his man!—For though the manſion-houſe and dirty acres have ſlipt through my fingers, I thank God our honour, and the family-pictures, are as freſh as ever.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: O Sir Lucius! I have had anceſtors too! every man of 'em colonel or captain in the militia?—Odds balls and barrels! ſay no more—I'm brac'd for it—my nerves are become catgut! my ſinews wire! and my heart Pinchbeck! The thunder of your words has ſoured the milk of human kindneſs in my breaſt!—Z—ds! as the man in the play ſays, "I could do ſuch deeds!"

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Come, come, there muſt be no paſſion at all in the caſe—theſe things ſhould always be done civilly.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: I muſt be in a paſſion, Sir Lucius—I muſt be in a rage—Dear Sir Lucius let me be in a rage, if you love me.—Come, here's pen and paper.
I would the ink were red!—Indite, I ſay, indite!—How ſhall I begin? Odds bullets and blades! I'll write a good bold hand, however.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pray compoſe yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Come—now ſhall I begin with an oath? Do, Sir Lucius, let me begin with a damme.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pho! pho! do the thing decently and like a Chriſtian. Begin now,—"Sir—

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: That's too civil by half.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: "To prevent the confuſion that might ariſe."

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Well—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: "From our both addreſſing the ſame lady."

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Aye—there's the reaſon—"ſame lady"— Well—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: "I ſhall expect the honour of your company"—

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Z—ds! I'm not aſking him to dinner.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pray be eaſy.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Well then, "honour of your company"

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: To ſettle our pretenſions."

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Let me ſee, aye, King's Mead-fields will do.—"In King's Mead fields."

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: So that's done.—Well, I'll fold it up preſently; my own creſt—a hand and dagger ſhall be the ſeal.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: You ſee now this little explanation will put a ſtop at once to all confuſion or miſunderſtanding that might ariſe between you.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Aye, we fight to prevent any miſunderſtanding.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Now, I'll leave you to fix your own time.—take my advice, and you'll decide it this evening if you can; then let the worſt come of it, 'twill be off your mind to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: So I ſhall ſee nothing more of you, unleſs it be by letter, till the evening.—I would do myſelf the honour to carry your meſſage; but, to tell you a ſecret, I believe I ſhall have juſt ſuch another affair on my own hands. There is a gay captain here, who put a jeſt on me lately, at the expence of my country, and I only want to fall in with the gentleman, to call him out.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: By my valour, I ſhould like to ſee you fight firſt! Odds life! I ſhould like to ſee you kill him, if it was only to get a little leſſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: I ſhall be very proud of inſtructing you. —Well for the preſent—but remember now, when you meet your antagoniſt, do every thing in a mild and agreeable manner.—Let your courage be as keen, but at the ſame time as poliſhed as your ſword.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: THEN, by the Maſs, Sir! I would do no ſuch thing—ne'er a Sir Lucius O'Trigger in the kingdom ſhould make me fight, when I wa'n't ſo minded. Oons! what will the old lady ſay, when ſhe hears o't!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Ah! David, if you had heard Sir Lucius!—Odds ſparks and flames! he would have rous'd your valour.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Not he, indeed. I hates ſuch bloodthirſty cormorants. Look'ee, Maſter, if you'd wanted a bout at boxing, quarter-ſtaff, or ſhortſtaff, I ſhould never be the man to bid you cry off: But for your curſt ſharps and ſnaps, I never knew any good come of 'em.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: But my honour, David, my honour! I muſt be very careful of my honour.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Aye, by the Maſs! and I would be very careful of it; and I think in return my honour couldn't do leſs than to be very careful of me.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Odds blades! David, no gentleman will ever riſk the loſs of his honour!

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p:
I ſay then, it would be but civil in honour never to riſk the loſs of the gentleman.— Lookee, Maſter, this honour ſeems to me to be a marvellous
falſe friend; aye, truly, a very courtier-like ſervant.—Put the caſe, I was a gentleman (which, thank God, no one can ſay of me); well—my honour makes me quarrel with another gentleman of my acquaintance.—So—we fight. (Pleaſant enough that) Boh!—I kill him—(the more's my luck.) Now, pray who gets the profit of it?—Why, my honour.—But put the caſe that he kills me!— by the Maſs! I go to the worms, and my honour whips over to my enemy!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: No, David—in that caſe!—Odds crowns and laurels! your honour follows you to the grave.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Now, that's juſt the place where I could make a ſhift to do without it.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Z—ds, David! you're a coward!— It doesn't become my valour to liſten to you.— What, ſhall I diſgrace my anceſtors?—Think of that, David—think what it would be to diſgrace my anceſtors!

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Under favour, the ſureſt way of not diſgracing them, is to keep as long as you can out of their company. Look'ee now, Maſter, to go to them in ſuch haſte—with an ounce of lead in your brains—I ſhould think might as well be let alone. Our anceſtors are very good kind of folks; but they are the laſt people I ſhould chooſe to have a viſiting acquaintance with.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: But David, now, you don't think there is ſuch very, very, very great danger, hey?— Odds life! people often fight without any miſchief done!

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p:
By the Maſs, I think 'tis ten to one againſt you!—Oons! here to meet ſome lionheaded fellow, I warrant, with his d—n'd doublebarrell'd ſwords, and cut and thruſt piſtols! Lord bleſs us! it makes me tremble to think o't!— Thoſe be ſuch deſperate bloody-minded weapons!
Well, I never could abide 'em!—from a child I never could fancy 'em!—I ſuppoſe there a'n't ſo mercileſs a beaſt in the world as your loaded piſtol!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Z—ds! I won't be afraid—Odds fire and fury! you ſhan't make me afraid.—Here is the challenge, and I have ſent for my dear friend Jack Abſolute to carry it for me.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Aye, I'the name of miſchief, let him be the meſſenger.—For my part, I wouldn't lend a hand to it for the beſt horſe in your ſtable. By the Maſs! it don't look like another letter!—It is, as I may ſay, a deſigning and malicious-looking letter!—and I warrant ſmells of gunpowder like a ſoldier's pouch!—Oons! I wouldn't ſwear it mayn't go off!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Out, you poltroon!—you ha'n't the valour of a graſs-hopper.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Well, I ſay no more—'twill be ſad news, to be ſure, at Clod-Hall!—but I ha' done.—How Phyllis will howl when ſhe hears of it!—Aye, poor bitch, ſhe little thinks what ſhooting her Maſter's going after!—And I warrant old Crop, who has carried your honour, field and road, theſe ten years, will curſe the hour he was born.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: It won't do, David—I am determined to fight—ſo get along, you Coward, while I'm in the mind.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Captain Abſolute, Sir.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: O! ſhew him up.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Well, Heaven ſend we be all alive this time to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: What's that!—Don't provoke me, David!

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Good bye, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Getalong, you cowardly, daſtardly, croaking raven.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: What's the matter, Bob?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: A vile, ſheep-hearted blockhead!—If I hadn't the valour of St. George and the dragon to boot—

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: But what did you want with me, Bob?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: O!—There—(Gives him the challenge.)

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: "To Enſign Beverley." So—what's going on now!
Well, what's this?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: A challenge!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Indeed!—Why, you won't fight him; will you, Bob?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: 'Egad but I will, Jack.—Sir Lucius has wrought me to it. He has left me full of rage—and I'll fight this evening, that ſo much good paſſion mayn't be waſted.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: But what have I to do with this?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Why, as I think you know ſomething of this fellow, I want you to find him out for me, and give him this mortal defiance.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Well, give it to me, and truſt me he gets it.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Thank you, my dear friend, my dear Jack; but it is giving you a great deal of trouble.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt—I beg you won't mention it.—No trouble in the world, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: You are very kind.—What it is to have a friend!—You couldn't be my ſecond— could you, Jack?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Why no, Bob—not in this affair—it would not be quite ſo proper.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Well then I muſt fix on my friend Sir Lucius. I ſhall have your good wiſhes, however, Jack.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Whenever he meets you, believe me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir Anthony Abſolute is below, inquiring for the Captain.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: I'll come inſtantly.—Well, my little hero, ſucceſs attend you.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Stay—ſtay, Jack.—If Beverley ſhould aſk you what kind of a man your friend Acres is, do, tell him I am a devil of a fellow—will you, Jack?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: To be ſure I ſhall.—I'll ſay you are a determined dog—hey, Bob!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Aye, do, do—and if that frightens him, 'egad perhaps he mayn't come. So tell him I generally kill a man a week; will you, Jack!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: I will, I will; I'll ſay you are call'd in the country "Fighting Bob!"

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Right, right—'tis all to prevent miſchief; for I don't want to take his life if I clear my honour.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: No!—that's very kind of you.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Why, you don't wiſh me to kill him—do you, Jack?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: No, upon my ſoul, I do not.—But a devil of a fellow, hey?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: True, true—but ſtay—ſtay, Jack—you may add that you never ſaw me in ſuch a rage before —a moſt devouring rage!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: I will, I will.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Remember, Jack—a determined dog!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Aye, aye, "Fighting Bob!"

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p:
Why, thou perverſe one!—tell me what you can object to him?—Isn't he a handſome
man?—tell me that.—A genteel man? a pretty figure of a man?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: She little thinks whom ſhe is praiſing! (aſide)—So is Beverley, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: No capariſons, Miſs, if you pleaſe! —Capariſons don't become a young woman.—No! Captain Abſolute is indeed a fine gentleman!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Aye, the Captain Abſolute you have ſeen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Then he's ſo well bred;—ſo full of alacrity, and adulation!—and has ſo much to ſay for himſelf:—in ſuch good language too!—His phyſiognomy ſo grammatical!—Then his preſence is ſo noble!—I proteſt, when I ſaw him, I thought of what Hamlet ſays in the Play:—Heſperian curls!—the front of Job himſelf!—an eye, like March, to threaten at command!—a Station, like Harry Mercury, new— Something about kiſſing—on a hill—however, the ſimilitudé ſtruck me directly.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: How enraged ſhe'll be preſently when ſhe diſcovers her miſtake!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir Anthony, and Captain Abſolute are below Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Shew them up here. [Exit Serv. Now, Lydia, I inſiſt on your behaving as becomes a young woman.—Shew your good breeding at leaſt, though you have forgot your duty.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Madam, I have told you my reſolution;—I ſhall not only give him no encouragement, but I won't even ſpeak to, or look at him.

div.stage: [Flings herſelf into a chair, with her face from the door.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p:
Here we are, Mrs. Malaprop; come to mitigate the frowns of unrelenting beauty—and
difficulty enough I had to bring this fellow.—I don't know what's the matter; but if I hadn't held him by force, he'd have given me the ſlip.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: You have infinite trouble, Sir Anthony, in the affair.—I am aſhamed for the cauſe! Lydia, Lydia, riſe I beſeech you!—pay your reſpects!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, that Miſs Languiſh has reflected on the worth of this gentleman, and the regard due to her Aunt's choice, and my alliance. —Now, Jack, ſpeak to her!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: What the d—I ſhall I do!—(Aſide)—You ſee, Sir, ſhe won't even look at me, whilſt you are here.—I knew ſhe wouldn't!—I told you ſo—Let me intreat you, Sir, to leave us together!

div.stage: [Abſolute ſeems to expoſtulate with his Father.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: (aſide.) I wonder I ha'n't heard my Aunt exclaim yet! ſure ſhe can't have look'd at him! —perhaps their regimentals are alike, and ſhe is ſomething blind.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I ſay, Sir, I won't ſtir a foot yet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: I am ſorry to ſay, Sir Anthony, that my affluence over my Niece is very ſmall.—Turn round Lydia, I bluſh for you!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: May I not flatter myſelf that Miſs Languiſh will aſſign what cauſe of diſlike ſhe can have to my ſon!—Why don't you begin, Jack?— Speak, you puppy—ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: It is impoſſible, Sir Anthony, ſhe can have any.—She will not ſay ſhe has.— Anſwer, huſſy! why don't you anſwer?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Then, Madam, I truſt that a childiſh and haſty predilection will be no bar to Jack's happineſs.—Z—ds! ſirrah! why don't you ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
(aſide) I think my lover ſeems as little inclined
to converſation as myſelf.—How ſtrangely blind my Aunt is!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Hem! hem!—Madam—hem! (Abſolute attempts to ſpeak, then returns to Sir Anthony)— Faith! Sir, I am ſo confounded!—and ſo—ſo— confuſed!—I told you I ſhould be ſo, Sir,—I knew it—The-the-tremor of my paſſion, entirely takes away my preſence of mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: But it don't take away your voice, fool, does it?—Go up, and ſpeak to her directly! [Abſ. makes ſigns to Mrs. Mal. to leave them together.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Sir Anthony, ſhall we leave them together? —Ah! you ſtubborn, little vixen!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Not yet, Ma'am, not yet!—what the d—l are you at? unlock your jaws, ſirrah, or—

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Now Heav'n ſend ſhe may be too ſullen to look round!—I muſt diſguiſe my voice—(Aſide)—
—Will not Miſs Languiſh lend an ear to the mild accents of true love?—Will not—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: What the d—l ails the fellow?— Why don't you ſpeak out?—not ſtand croaking like a frog in a quinſey!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: The—the—exceſs of my awe, and my—my— my modeſty, quite choak me!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Ah! your modeſty again!—I'll tell you what, Jack; if you don't ſpeak out directly, and glibly too, I ſhall be in ſuch a rage!—Mrs. Malaprop, I wiſh the lady would favour us with ſomething more than a ſide-front!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: So!—all will out I ſee!
Be not ſurpriſed, my Lydia, ſuppreſs all ſurpriſe at preſent.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: (aſide) Heav'ns! 'tis Beverley's voice!— Sure he can't have impos'd on Sir Anthony too!—
sp.stage: [Looks round by degrees, then ſtarts up.
sp.p: Is this poſſible!—my Beverley!—how can this be? —my Beverley?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Ah! 'tis all over.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Beverley!—the devil—Beverley!— What can the girl mean?—This is my ſon, Jack Abſolute!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: For ſhame, huſſy! for ſhame!— your head runs ſo on that fellow, that you have him always in your eyes!—beg Captain Abſolute's pardon directly.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I ſee no Captain Abſolute, but my lov'd Beverley!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Z—ds! the girl's mad!—her brain's turn'd by reading!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O' my conſcience, I believe ſo!— what do you mean by Beverley, huſſy?—You ſaw Captain Abſolute before to-day; there he is— your huſband that ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: With all my ſoul, Ma'am—when I refuſe my Beverley—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: O! ſhe's as mad as Bedlam!—or has this fellow been playing us a rogue's trick!—Come here, ſirrah! who the d—l are you?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I am not quite clear myſelf; but I'll endeavour to recollect.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Are you my ſon, or not?—anſwer for your mother, you dog, if you won't for me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, who are you? O mercy! I begin to ſuſpect!—

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p:
Ye Powers of Impudence befriend me! (aſide) Sir Anthony, moſt aſſuredly I am your wife's ſon; and that I ſincerely believe myſelf to be your's alſo, I hope my duty has always ſhewn. —Mrs. Malaprop, I am your moſt reſpectful admirer —and ſhall be proud to add affectionate nephew.
—I need not tell my Lydia, that ſhe ſees her faithful Beverley, who, knowing the ſingular generoſity of her temper, aſſum'd that name, and a ſtation, which has proved a teſt of the moſt diſintereſted love, which he now hopes to enjoy in a a more elevated character.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: So!—there will be no elopement after all!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, Jack, thou art a very impudent fellow! to do you juſtice, I think I never ſaw a piece of more conſummate aſſurance!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O, you flatter me, Sir—you compliment— 'tis my modeſty you know, Sir—my modeſty that has ſtood in my way.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Well, I am glad you are not the dull, inſenſible varlet you pretended to be, however!— I'm glad you have made a fool of your father, you dog—I am.—So this was your penitence, your duty, and obedience!—I thought it was d—n'd ſudden! —You never heard their names before, not you! —What, Languiſhes of Worceſterſhire, hey?—if you could pleaſe me in the affair, 'twas all you deſired!— Ah! you diſſembling villain!—What! (pointing to Lydia) ſhe ſquints, don't ſhe?—a little red-hair'd girl!—hey?—Why, you hypocritical young raſcal —I wonder you a'n't aſham'd to hold up your head!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: 'Tis with difficulty, Sir—I am confus'd— very much confus'd, as you muſt perceive.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O Lud! Sir Anthony!—a new light breaks in upon me!—hey! how! what! Captain, did you write the letters then?—What!—I am to thank you for the elegant compilation of 'an old weather-beaten ſhe-dragon'—hey?—O mercy!—was it you that reflected on my parts of ſpeech?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Dear Sir! my modeſty will be overpower'd at laſt, if you don't aſſiſt me.—I ſhall certainly not be able to ſtand it!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come, come, Mrs. Malaprop, we muſt forget and forgive;—odds'life! matters have taken ſo clever a turn all of a ſudden, that I could find in my heart, to be ſo good-humour'd! and ſo gallant!—hey! Mrs. Malaprop!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Well, Sir Anthony, ſince you deſire it, we will not anticipate the paſt;—ſo mind young people—our retroſpection will now be all to the future.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come, we muſt leave them together; Mrs. Malaprop, they long to fly into each other's arms, I warrant!—Jack—is'n't the cheek as I ſaid, hey?—and the eye, you dog!—and the lip—hey? Come, Mrs. Malaprop, we'll not diſturb their tenderneſs—their's is the time of life for happineſs! —"Youth's the ſeaſon made for joy"—(ſings) —hey!—Odds'life! I'm in ſuch ſpirits,—I don't know what I couldn't do!—Permit me, Ma'am— (gives his hand to Mrs. Mal.) (ſings) Tol-de-rol— 'gad I ſhould like a little fooling myſelf—Tol-derol! de-rol!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: So much thought bodes me no good (aſide) —So grave, Lydia!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: So!—egad! I thought as much!—that d—n'd monoſyllable has froze me! (aſide)—What, Lydia, now that we are as happy in our friends conſent, as in our mutual vows—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Friends conſent, indeed! (peeviſhly)

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Come, come, we muſt lay aſide ſome of our romance—a little wealth and comfort may be endur'd after all. And for your fortune, the lawyers ſhall make ſuch ſettlements as—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Lawyers! I hate lawyers!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Nay then, we will not wait for their lingering forms, but inſtantly procure the licence, and—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: The licence!—I hate licence!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O my Love! be not ſo unkind!—thus let me intreat—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Pſhaw!—what ſignifies kneeling, when you know I muſt have you?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: (riſing) Nay, Madam, there ſhall be no conſtraint upon your inclinations, I promiſe you. —If I have loſt your heart,—I reſign the reſt.— 'Gad, I muſt try what a little ſpirit will do.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: (riſing) Then, Sir, let me tell you, the intereſt you had there was acquired by a mean, unmanly impoſition, and deſerves the puniſhment of fraud.—What, you have been treating me like a child!—humouring my romance! and laughing, I ſuppoſe, at your ſucceſs!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: You wrong me, Lydia, you wrong me— only hear—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: So, while I fondly imagined we were deceiving my relations, and flatter'd myſelf that I ſhould outwit and incenſe them all—behold! my hopes are to be cruſh'd at once, by my Aunt's conſent and approbation!—and I am myſelf, the only dupe at laſt!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Nay, but hear me—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: No, Sir, you could not think that ſuch paltry artifices could pleaſe me, when the maſk was thrown off!—But I ſuppoſe ſince your tricks have made you ſecure of my fortune, you are little ſolicitous about my affections.—But here, Sir, here is the picture—Beverley's picture! (taking a miniature from her boſom) which I have worn, night and day, in ſpite of threats and entreaties!— There, Sir, (flings it to him) and be aſſured I throw the original from my heart as eaſily!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, Ma'am, we will not differ as to that.—Here, (taking out a picture) here is Miſs Lydia Languiſh.—What a difference!—aye, there is the heav'nly aſſenting ſmile, that firſt gave ſoul
and ſpirit to my hopes!—thoſe are the lips which ſeal'd a vow, as yet ſcarce dry in Cupid's calendar! —and there the half reſentful bluſh, that would have check'd the ardour of my thanks—Well, all that's paſt!—all over indeed!—There, Madam— in beauty, that copy is not equal to you, but in my mind it's merit over the original, in being ſtill the ſame, is ſuch—that—I cannot find in my heart to part with it.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: (Softening) 'Tis your own doing, Sir—I, I, I ſuppoſe you are perfectly ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O, moſt certainly—ſure now this is much better than being in love!—ha! ha! ha!—there's ſome ſpirit in this!—What ſignifies breaking ſome ſcores of ſolemn promiſes, half an hundred vows, under one's hand, with the marks of a dozen or two angels to witneſs—all that's of no conſequence you know.—To be ſure people will ſay, that Miſs didn't know her own mind—but never mind that:— or perhaps they may be ill-natured enough to hint, that the gentleman grew tired of the lady and forſook her—but don't let that fret you.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: There's no bearing his inſolence.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Malaprop and Sir Anthony.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: (Entering) Come, we muſt interrupt your billing and cooing a while.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: This is worſe than your treachery and deceit, you baſe ingrate!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: What the devil's the matter now!— Z—ds! Mrs. Malaprop, this is the oddeſt billing and cooing I ever heard!—but what the deuce is the meaning of it?—I'm quite aſtoniſh'd!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Aſk the lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O mercy!—I'm quite analys'd for my part!—why, Lydia, what is the reaſon of this?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Aſk the gentleman, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Z—ds! I ſhall be in a phrenzy!— why Jack, you ſcoundrel, you are not come out to be any one elſe, are you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, there's no more trick, is there?—you are not like Cerberus, three Gentlemen at once, are you?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: You'll not let me ſpeak—I ſay the lady can account for this much better than I can.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Ma'am, you once commanded me never to think of Beverley again—there is the man—I now obey you:—for, from this moment, I renounce him for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O mercy! and miracles! what a turn here is—why ſure, Captain, you haven't behaved diſreſpectfully to my Niece.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—ha! ha! ha!—now I ſee it—Ha! ha! ha!—now I ſee it—you have been too lively, Jack.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, upon my word—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come, no lying, Jack—I'm ſure 'twas ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O Lud! Sir Anthony!—O fie, Captain!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come, no excuſes, Jack;—why, your father, you rogue, was ſo before you:—the blood of the Abſolutes was always impatient.—Ha! ha! ha! poor little Lydia!—why, you've frighten'd her, you Dog, you have.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: By all that's good, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p:
Z—ds! ſay no more, I tell you.— Mrs. Malaprop ſhall make your peace.—You muſt make his peace, Mrs. Malaprop;—you muſt tell her 'tis Jack's way—tell her 'tis all our ways— it runs in the blood of our family!—Come, get on,
Jack,—ha! ha! ha! Mrs. Malaprop—a young villain!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O! Sir Anthony!—O fie, Captain!

div.head: SCENE IV.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: I wonder where this Capt. Abſolute hides himſelf.—Upon my conſcience!—theſe officers are always in one's way in love-affairs:—I remember I might have married Lady Dorothy Carmine, if it had not been for a little rogue of a Major, who ran away with her before ſhe could get a ſight of me!—And I wonder too what it is the ladies can ſee in them to be ſo fond of them—unleſs it be a touch of the old ſerpent in 'em, that makes the little creatures be caught, like vipers with a bit of red cloth.—Hah!—isn't this the Captain coming? —faith it is!—There is a probability of ſucceeding about that fellow, that is mighty provoking! —Who the devil is he talking to?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: To what fine purpoſe I have been plotting! a noble reward for all my ſchemes, upon my ſoul!—a little gypſey!—I did not think her romance could have made her ſo d—n'd abſurd either—S'death, I never was in a worſe humour in my life!—I could cut my own throat, or any other perſon's, with the greateſt pleaſure in the world!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p:
O, faith! I'm in the luck of it—I never could have found him in a ſweeter temper for
my purpoſe—to be ſure I'm juſt come in the nick! now to enter into converſation with him, and ſo quarrel genteelly. [Sir Lucius goes up to Abſolute. —With regard to that matter, Captain, I muſt beg leave to differ in opinion with you.

sp.speaker: Abſ
sp.p: Upon my word then, you muſt be a very ſubtle diſputant:—becauſe, Sir, I happen'd juſt then to be giving no opinion at all.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: That's no reaſon.—For give me leave to tell you, a man may think an untruth as well as ſpeak one.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Very true, Sir, but if the man never utters his thoughts, I ſhould think they might ſtand a chance of eſcaping controverſy.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you differ in opinion with me, which amounts to the ſame thing.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Hark'ee, Sir Lucius,—if I had not before known you to be a gentleman, upon my ſoul, I ſhould not have diſcovered it at this interview:— for what you can drive at, unleſs you mean to quarrel with me, I cannot conceive!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: I humbly thank you, Sir, for the quickneſs of your apprehenſion, [Bowing. —you have nam'd the very thing I would be at.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—I ſhall certainly not baulk your inclinations:—but I ſhould be glad you would pleaſe to explain your motives.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, be eaſy—the quarrel is a very pretty quarrel as it ſtands—we ſhould only ſpoil it, by trying to explain it.—However, your memory is very ſhort—or you could not have forgot an affront you paſs'd on me within this week.—So no more, but name your time and place.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Well, Sir, ſince you are ſo bent on it, the ſooner the better;—let it be this evening—here, by the Spring-Gardens.—We ſhall ſcarcely be interrupted.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Faith! that ſame interruption in affairs of this nature, ſhews very great ill-breeding.— I don't know what's the reaſon, but in England, if a thing of this kind gets wind, people make ſuch a pother, that a gentleman can never fight in peace and quietneſs.—However, if it's the ſame to you, Captain, I ſhould take it as a particular kindneſs, if you'd let us meet in King's-Mead-Fields, as a little buſineſs will call me there about ſix o'clock, and I may diſpatch both matters at once.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: 'Tis the ſame to me exactly.—A little after ſix, then we will diſcuſs this matter more ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Sir, there will be very pretty ſmall-ſword light, tho' it won't do for a long ſhot.—So that matter's ſettled! and my mind's at eaſe.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Well met.—I was going to look for you.— O, Faulkand! all the Daemons of ſpite and diſappointment have conſpired againſt me! I'm ſo vex'd, that if I had not the proſpect of a reſource in being knock'd o'the head by and bye, I ſhould ſcarce have ſpirits to tell you the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: What can you mean?—Has Lydia chang'd her mind?—I ſhould have thought her duty and inclination would now have pointed to the ſame object.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Aye, juſt as the eyes do of a perſon who ſquints:—when her love-eye was fix'd on me— t'other—her eye of duty, was finely obliqued:—but when duty bid her point that the ſame way—off t'other turn'd on a ſwivel, and ſecured its retreat with a frown!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: But what's the reſource you—

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p:
O, to wind up the whole, a good natured Iriſhman here has (mimicking Sir Lucius) beg'd
leave to have the pleaſure of cutting my throat— and I mean to indulge him—that's all.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Prithee, be ſerious.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: 'Tis fact, upon my ſoul.—Sir Lucius O'Trigger—you know him by ſight—for ſome affront, which I am ſure I never intended, has obliged me to meet him this evening at ſix o'clock: —'tis on that account I wiſh'd to ſee you—you muſt go with me.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Nay, there muſt be ſome miſtake, ſure. —Sir Lucius ſhall explain himſelf—and I dare ſay matters may be accommodated:—but this evening, did you ſay?—I wiſh it had been any other time.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Why?—there will be light enough:— there will (as Sir Lucius ſays) "be very pretty ſmall-ſword light, tho' it won't do for a long ſhot."—Confound his long ſhots!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: But I am myſelf a good deal ruffled, by a difference I have had with Julia—my vile tormenting temper has made me treat her ſo cruelly, that I ſhall not be myſelf till we are reconciled.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: By Heav'ns, Faulkland, you don't deſerve her.

div.stage: Enter Servant, gives Faulkland a letter.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: O Jack! this is from Julia—I dread to open it—I fear it may be to take a laſt leave— perhaps to bid me return her letters—and reſtore —O! how I ſuffer for my folly!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Here—let me ſee.
Aye, a final ſentence indeed!—'tis all over with you, faith!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Nay, Jack—don't keep me in ſuſpence.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Hear then.—As

body.p:
I am convinced that my dear Faulkland's own reflections have already upbraided
braided him for his laſt unkindneſs to me, I will not add a word on the ſubject.—I wiſh to ſpeak with you as ſoon as poſſible.

sp.p: —There's ſtubbornneſs and reſentment for you!
Why, man, you don't ſeem one whit the happier at this.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: O, yes, I am—but—but—

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Confound your buts.—You never hear any thing that would make another man bleſs himſelf, but you immediately d—n it with a but.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Now, Jack, as you are my friend, own honeſtly—don't you think there is ſomething forward —ſomething indelicate in this haſte to forgive? —Women ſhould never ſue for reconciliation: —that ſhould always come from us.—They ſhould retain their coldneſs till woo'd to kindneſs— and their pardon, like their love, ſhould not unſought be won.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: I have not patience to liſten to you:— thou'rt incorrigible!—ſo ſay no more on the ſubject. —I muſt go to ſettle a few matters—let me ſee you before ſix—remember—at my lodgings.— A poor induſtrious devil like me, who have toil'd, and drudg'd, and plotted to gain my ends, and am at laſt diſappointed by other people's folly—may in pity be allowed to ſwear and grumble a little;— but a captious ſceptic in love,—a ſlave to fretfulneſs and whim—who has no difficulties but of his own creating—is a ſubject more fit for ridicule than compaſſion!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p:
I feel his reproaches!—yet I would not change this too exquiſite nicety, for the groſs content with which he tramples on the thorns of love. —His engaging me in this duel, has ſtarted an idea in my head, which I will inſtantly purſue.— I'll uſe it as the touch-ſtone of Julia's ſincerity and
diſintereſtedneſs—if her love prove pure and ſterling ore—my name will reſt on it with honour!— and once I've ſtamp'd it there, I lay aſide my doubts for ever:—but if the droſs of ſelfiſhneſs, the allay of pride predominate—'twill be beſt to leave her as a toy for ſome leſs cautious Fool to ſigh for.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.p: How this meſſage has alarmed me! what dreadful accident can he mean! why ſuch charge to be alone?—O Faulkland!—how many unhappy moments!—how many tears have you coſt me!

div.stage: Enter Faulkland, muffled up in a Riding-coat.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What means this?—why this caution, Faulkland?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Alas! Julia, I am come to take a long farewell.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Heav'ns! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: You ſee before you a wretch, whoſe life is forfeited.—Nay, ſtart not!—the infirmity of my temper has drawn all this miſery on me.—I left you fretful and paſſionate—an untoward accident drew me into a quarrel—the event is, that I muſt fly this kingdom inſtantly.—O Julia, had I been ſo fortunate as to have call'd you mine intirely, before this miſchance had fallen on me, I ſhould not ſo deeply dread my baniſhment!—But no more of that—your heart and promiſe were given to one happy in friends, character, and ſtation! they are not bound to wait upon a ſolitary, guilty exile.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My ſoul is oppreſs'd with ſorrow at the nature of your misfortune: had theſe adverſe circumſtances ariſen from a leſs fatal cauſe, I ſhould have felt ſtrong comfort in the thought that I could now chaſe from your boſom every doubt of the warm ſincerity of my love.—My heart has long known no other guardian—I now entruſt my perſon to your honour—we will fly together.—When ſafe from purſuit, my Father's will may be fulfilled —and I receive a legal claim to be the partner of your ſorrows, and tendereſt comforter. Then on the boſom of your wedded Julia, you may lull your keen regret to ſlumbering; while virtuous love, with a Cherub's hand, ſhall ſmooth the brow of upbraiding thought, and pluck the thorn from compunction.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: O Julia! I am bankrupt in gratitude! but the time is ſo preſſing, it calls on you for ſo haſty a reſolution.—Would you not wiſh ſome hours to weigh the advantages you forego, and what little compenſation poor Faulkland can make you beſide his ſolitary love?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I aſk not a moment.—No, Faulkland, I have lov'd you for yourſelf: and if I now, more than ever, prize the ſolemn engagement which ſo long has pledged us to each other, it is becauſe it leaves no room for hard aſperſions on my fame, and puts the ſeal of duty to an act of love.—But let us not linger.—Perhaps this delay—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: 'Twill be better I ſhould not venture out again till dark.—Yet am I griev'd to think what numberleſs diſtreſſes will preſs heavy on your gentle diſpoſition!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Perhaps your fortune may be forfeited by this unhappy act.—I know not whether 'tis ſo— but ſure that alone can never make us unhappy.— The little I have will be ſufficient to ſupport us; and exile never ſhould be ſplendid.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Aye, but in ſuch an abject ſtate of life, my wounded pride perhaps may increaſe the natural fretfulneſs of my temper, till I become a rude, moroſe companion, beyond your patience to endure. Perhaps the recollection of a deed, my conſcience cannot juſtify, may haunt me in ſuch gloomy and unſocial fits, that I ſhall hate the tenderneſs that would relieve me, break from your arms, and quarrel with your fondneſs!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If your thoughts ſhould aſſume ſo unhappy a bent, you will the more want ſome mild and affectionate ſpirit to watch over and conſole you:— One who, by bearing your infirmities with gentleneſs and reſignation, may teach you ſo to bear the evils of your fortune.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: O Julia, I have proved you to the quick! and with this uſeleſs device I throw away all my doubts. How ſhall I plead to be forgiven this laſt unworthy effect of my reſtleſs, unſatisfied diſpoſition?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Has no ſuch diſaſter happened as you related?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: I am aſhamed to own that it was all pretended; yet in pity, Julia, do not kill me with reſenting a fault which never can be repeated: But ſealing, this once, my pardon, let me to-morrow, in the face of Heaven, receive my future guide and monitreſs, and expiate my paſt folly, by years of tender adoration.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Hold, Faulkland!—that you are free from a crime, which I before fear'd to name, Heaven knows how ſincerely I rejoice!—Theſe are tears of thankfulneſs for that! But that your cruel doubts ſhould have urged you to an impoſition that has wrung my heart, gives me now a pang, more keen than I can expreſs!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: By Heav'ns! Julia—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yet hear me.—My Father lov'd you, Faulkland! and you preſerv'd the life that tender parent gave me; in his preſence I pledged my hand—joyfully pledged it—where before I had given my heart. When, ſoon after, I loſt that parent, it ſeem'd to me that Providence had, in Faulkland, ſhewn me whither to transfer, without a pauſe, my grateful duty, as well as my affection: Hence I have been content to bear from you what pride and delicacy would have forbid me from another.—I will not upbraid you, by repeating how you have trifled with my ſincerity.—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: I confeſs it all! yet hear—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: After ſuch a year of trial—I might have flattered myſelf that I ſhould not have been inſulted with a new probation of my ſincerity, as cruel as unneceſſary! A trick of ſuch a nature, as to ſhew me plainly, that when I thought you lov'd me beſt, you even then regarded me as a mean diſſembler; an artful, prudent hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Never! never!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I now ſee it is not in your nature to be content, or confident in love. With this conviction— I never will be yours. While I had hopes that my perſevering attention, and unreproaching kindneſs might in time reform your temper, I ſhould have been happy to have gain'd a dearer influence over you; but I will not furniſh you with a licenſed power to keep alive an incorrigible fault, at the expence of one who never would contend with you.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Nay, but Julia, by my ſoul and honour, if after this—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
But one word more.—As my faith has once been given to you, I never will barter it with another. —I ſhall pray for your happineſs with the trueſt ſincerity; and the deareſt bleſſing I can aſk of
Heaven to ſend you, will be to charm you from that unhappy temper, which alone has prevented the performance of our ſolemn engagement.—All I requeſt of you is, that you will yourſelf reflect upon this infirmity, and when you number up the many true delights it has deprived you of—let it not be your leaſt regret, that it loſt you the love of one— who would have follow'd you in beggary through the world!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: She's gone!—for ever!—There was an awful reſolution in her manner, that rivetted me to my place.—O Fool!—Dolt!—Barbarian!— Curſt as I am, with more imperfections than my fellow-wretches, kind Fortune ſent a heaven-gifted cherub to my aid, and, like a ruffian, I have driven her from my ſide!—I muſt now haſte to my appointment.—Well my mind is tuned for ſuch a ſcene.—I ſhall wiſh only to become a principal in it, and reverſe the tale my curſed folly put me upon forging here.—O Love!—Tormentor!— Fiend!—whoſe influence, like the Moon's, acting on men of dull ſouls, makes idiots of them, but meeting ſubtler ſpirits, betrays their courſe, and urges ſenſibility to madneſs!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: My Miſtreſs, Ma'am, I know, was here juſt now—perhaps ſhe is only in the next room.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Heigh ho!—Though he has uſed me ſo, this fellow runs ſtrangely in my head. I believe one lecture from my grave Couſin will make me recall him.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
O Julia, I am come to you with ſuch an appetite for conſolation.—Lud! Child, what's the matter with you?—You have been crying!—I'll
be hanged, if that Faulkland has not been tormenting you!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You miſtake the cauſe of my uneaſineſs.— Something has flurried me a little.—Nothing that you can gueſs at.—I would not accuſe Faulkland to a Siſter!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Ah! whatever vexations you may have, I can aſſure you mine ſurpaſs them.—You know who Beverley proves to be?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I will now own to you, Lydia, that Mr. Faulkland had before inform'd me of the whole affair. Had young Abſolute been the perſon you took him for, I ſhould not have accepted your confidence on the ſubject, without a ſerious endeavour to counteract your caprice.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: So, then, I ſee I have been deceived by every one!—but I don't care—I'll never have him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay, Lydia—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Why, is it not provoking; when I thought we were coming to the prettieſt diſtreſs imaginable, to find myſelf made a mere Smithfield bargain of at laſt—There had I projected one of the moſt ſentimental elopements!—ſo becoming a diſguiſe!—ſo amiable a ladder of Ropes!—Conſcious Moon—four horſes—Scotch parſon—with ſuch ſurpriſe to Mrs. Malaprop—and ſuch paragraphs in the News-papers!—O, I ſhall die with diſappointment.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I don't wonder at it!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Now—ſad reverſe!—what have I to expect, but, after a deal of flimſy preparation with a biſhop's licence, and my Aunt's bleſſing, to go ſimpering up to the Altar; or perhaps be cried three times in a country-church, and have an unmannerly fat clerk aſk the conſent of every butcher in the pariſh to join John Abſolute and Lydia Languiſh, Spinſter! O, that I ſhould live to hear myſelf called Spinſter!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Melancholy, indeed!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: How mortifying, to remember the dear delicious ſhifts I uſed to be put to, to gain half a minute's converſation with this fellow!—How often have I ſtole forth, in the coldeſt night in January, and found him in the garden, ſtuck like a dripping ſtatue!—There would he kneel to me in the ſnow, and ſneeze and cough ſo pathetically! he ſhivering with cold, and I with apprehenſion! and while the freezing blaſt numb'd our joints, how warmly would he preſs me to pity his flame, and glow with mutual ardour!—Ah, Julia! that was ſomething like being in love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If I were in ſpirits, Lydia, I ſhould chide you only by laughing heartily at you: but it ſuits more the ſituation of my mind, at preſent, earneſtly to entreat you, not to let a man, who loves you with ſincerity, ſuffer that unhappineſs from your caprice, which I know too well caprice can inflict.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: O Lud! what has brought my Aunt here!

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Malaprop, Fag, and David.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: So! ſo! here's fine work!—here's fine ſuicide, paracide, and ſalivation going on in the fields! and Sir Anthony not to be found to prevent the antiſtrophe!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake, Madam, what's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: That gentleman can tell you—'twas he enveloped the affair to me.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Do, Sir, will you inform us.

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: Ma'am, I ſhould hold myſelf very deficient in every requiſite that forms the man of breeding, if I delay'd a moment to give all the information in my power to a lady ſo deeply intereſted in the affair as you are.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But quick! quick, Sir!

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: True, Ma'am, as you ſay, one ſhould be quick in divulging matters of this nature; for ſhould we be tedious, perhaps while we are flouriſhing on the ſubject, two or three lives may be loſt!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: O patience!—Do, Ma'am, for Heaven's ſake! tell us what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Why, murder's the matter! ſlaughter's the matter! killing's the matter!—but he can tell you the perpendiculars.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Then, prythee, Sir, be brief.

Why then, Ma'am—as to murder—I can
•••
• ake upon me to ſay—and as to ſlaughter, or man-ſlaughter, that will be as the jury finds it.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But who, Sir—who are engaged in this?

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: Faith, Ma'am, one is a young gentleman whom I ſhould be very ſorry any thing was to happen to—a very pretty behaved gentleman!—We have lived much together, and always on terms.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But who is this? who! who! who!

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: My Maſter, Ma'am—my Maſter—I ſpeak of my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Heavens! What, Captain Abſolute!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O, to be ſure, you are frightened now!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But who are with him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: As to the reſt, Ma'am, his gentleman can inform you better than I.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Do ſpeak, friend.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Look'ee, my Lady—by the Maſs! there's miſchief going on.—Folks don't uſe to meet for amuſement with fire-arms, firelocks, fire-engines, fire-ſcreens, fire-office, and the devil knows what other crackers beſides!—This, my Lady, I ſay, has an angry favour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But who is there beſide Captain Abſolute, friend?

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p:
My poor Maſter—under favour, for mentioning him firſt.—You know me, my Lady—
I am David—and my Maſter of courſe is, or was Squire Acres.—Then comes Squire Faulkland.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Do, Ma'am, let us inſtantly endeavour to prevent miſchief.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O fie—it would be very inelegant in us:—we ſhould only participate things.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Ah! do, Mrs. Aunt, ſave a few lives— they are deſperately given, believe me.—Above all, there is that blood-thirſty Philiſtine, Sir Lucius O'Trigger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Sir Lucius O'Trigger!—O mercy! have they drawn poor little dear Sir Lucius into the ſcrape?—why, how you ſtand, girl! you have no more e eling than one of the Derbyſhire Putrefactions!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: What are we to do, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Why, fly with the utmoſt felicity to be ſure, to prevent miſchief:—here, friend— you can ſhew us the place?

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Ma'am, I will conduct you. —David, do you look for Sir Anthony.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Come, girls!—this gentleman will exhort us.—Come, Sir, you're our envoy—lead the way, and we'll precede.

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: Not a ſtep before the ladies for the world!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: You're ſure you know the ſpot.

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: I think I can find it, Ma'am; and one good thing is, we ſhall hear the report of the piſtols as we draw near, ſo we can't well miſs them; never fear, Ma'am, never fear.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Abſolute, putting his ſword under his greatcoat.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: A ſword ſeen in the ſtreets of Bath would raiſe as great an alarm as a mad-dog.—How provoking this is in Faulkland!—never punctual! I ſhall be obliged to go without him at laſt.—O, the devil! here's Sir Anthony!—how ſhall I eſcape him?

div.stage: [Muffles up his face, and takes a circle to go off.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: How one may be deceived at a little diſtance! only that I ſee he don't know me, I could have ſworn that was Jack!—Hey!—'Gad's life; it is.—Why, Jack, you Dog!—what are you afraid of?—hey! ſure I'm right.—Why, Jack— Jack Abſolute!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Really, Sir, you have the advantage of me: —I don't remember ever to have had the honour —my name is Saunderſon, at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your pardon—I took you— hey!—why, z—ds! it is—Stay—
So, ſo—your humble ſervant, Mr. Saunderſon!— Why, you ſcoundrel, what tricks are you after now?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O! a joke, Sir, a joke!—I came here on purpoſe to look for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: You did! well, I am glad you were ſo lucky:—but what are you muffled up ſo for? —what's this for?—hey?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p:
Tis cool, Sir; isn't it?—rather chilly ſomehow—
but I ſhall be late—I have a particular engagement.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Stay.—why, I thought you were looking for me?—Pray, Jack, where is't you are going?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Going, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Aye—where are you going?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Where am I going?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: You unmannerly puppy!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: I was going, Sir, to—to—to—to Lydia— Sir to Lydia—to make matters up if I could;— and I was looking for you, Sir, to—to—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: To go with you, I ſuppoſe—Well, come along.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O! z—ds! no, Sir, not for the world!— I wiſh'd to meet with you, Sir, to—to—to— You find it cool, I'm ſure, Sir—you'd better not ſtay out.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Cool!—not at all—Well, Jack—and what will you ſay to Lydia?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O, Sir, beg her pardon, humour her—promiſe and vow:—but I detain you, Sir—conſider the cold air on your gout.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: O, not at all!—not at all!—I'm in no hurry.—Ah! Jack, you youngſters when once you are wounded here.
Hey! what the deuce have you got here?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir—nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: What's this?—here's ſomething d—d hard!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O, trinkets, Sir! trinkets—a bauble for Lydia!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Nay, let me ſee your taſte.
sp.stage: [Pulls his coat open, the ſword falls.
sp.p: Trinkets!—a bauble for Lydia!—z—ds! ſirrah, you are not going to cut her throat, are you?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha!—I thought it would divert
you, Sir, tho' I didn't mean to tell you till afterwards.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: You didn't?—Yes, this is a very diverting trinket, truly.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Sir, I'll explain to you.—You know, Sir, Lydia is romantic—dev'liſh romantic, and very abſurd of courſe:—now, Sir, I intend, if ſhe refuſes to forgive me—to unſheath this ſword—and ſwear—I'll fall upon its point, and expire at her feet!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Fall upon fiddle-ſticks end!—why, I ſuppoſe it is the very thing that would pleaſe her—Get along, you Fool.—

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you ſhall hear of my ſucceſs— you ſhall hear.—"O, Lydia!—forgive me, or this pointed ſteel"—ſays I.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: "O, Booby! ſtab away, and welcome" —ſays ſhe—Get along!—and d—n your trinkets!

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Stop him! ſtop him! Murder! Thief! Fire!—Stop fire! Stop fire!—O! Sir Anthony— call! call! bid 'em ſtop! Murder! Fire!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Fire! Murder! where?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Oons! he's out of ſight! and I'm out of breath, for my part! O, Sir Anthony, why didn't you ſtop him? why didn't you ſtop him?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Z—ds! the fellow's mad!—Stop whom? ſtop Jack?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Aye, the Captain, Sir!—there's murder and ſlaughter—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Murder!

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Aye, pleaſe you, Sir Anthony, there's all kinds of murder, all ſorts of ſlaughter to be ſeen in the fields: there's fighting going on, Sir— bloody ſword-and-gun fighting!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Who are going to fight, Dunce?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Every body that I know of, Sir Anthony: —every body is going to fight, my poor Maſter, Sir Lucius O'Trigger, your ſon, the Captain—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: O, the Dog!—I ſee his tricks:—do you know the place?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: King's-Mead-Fields.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: You know the way?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Not an inch;—but I'll call the Mayor— Aldermen—Conſtables—Church-wardens—and Beadles—we can't be too many to part them.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come along—give me your ſhoulder! we'll get aſſiſtance as we go—the lying villain!— Well, I ſhall be in ſuch a phrenzy—So—this was the hiſtory of his d—d trinkets! I'll bauble him!

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Sir Lucius and Acres, with piſtols.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: By my valour! then, Sir Lucius, forty yards is a good diſtance—Odds levels and aims!— I ſay it is a good diſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Is it for muſkets or ſmall field-pieces? upon my conſcience, Mr. Acres, you muſt leave thoſe things to me.—Stay now—I'll ſhew you. [Meaſures paces along the ſtage. there now, that is a very pretty diſtance—a pretty gentleman's diſtance.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Z—ds! we might as well fight in a ſentrybox! —I tell you, Sir Lucius, the farther he is off, the cooler I ſhall take my aim.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Faith! then I ſuppoſe you would aim at him beſt of all if he was out of ſight!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: No, Sir Lucius—but I ſhould think forty or eight and thirty yards—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p:
Pho! pho! nonſenſe! three or four
feet between the mouths of your piſtols is as good as a mile.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Odds bullets, no!—by my valour! there is no merit in killing him ſo near:—do, my dear Sir Lucius, let me bring him down at a long ſhot:— a long ſhot, Sir Lucius, if you love me!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well—the gentleman's friend and I muſt ſettle that.—But tell me now, Mr. Acres, in caſe of an accident, is there any little will or commiſſion I could execute for you?

sp.speaker: Acres.
