sp.p: I am much obliged to you, Sir Lucius— but I don't underſtand—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Why, you may think there's no being ſhot at without a little riſk—and if an unlucky bullet ſhould carry a Quietus with it—I ſay it will be no time then to be bothering you about family matters.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: A Quietus!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: For inſtance now—if that ſhould be the caſe—would you chuſe to be pickled and ſent home?—or would it be the ſame to you to lie here in the Abbey?—I'm told there is very ſnug lying in the Abbey.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Pickled!—Snug lying in the Abbey!— Odds tremors! Sir Lucius, don't talk ſo!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe, Mr. Acres, you never were engaged in an affair of this kind before?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: No, Sir Lucius, never before.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Ah! that's a pity!—there's nothing like being uſed to a thing.—Pray now, how would you receive the gentleman's ſhot?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Odds files!—I've practiſed that—there, Sir Lucius—there [Puts himſelf in an attitude. —a ſide-front, hey?—Odd! I'll make myſelf ſmall enough:—I'll ſtand edge-ways.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Now—you're quite out—for if you ſtand ſo when I take my aim—

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Z—ds! Sir Lucius—are you ſure it is not cock'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Never fear.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: But—but—you don't know—it may go off of its own head!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pho! be eaſy—Well, now if I hit you in the body, my bullet has a double chance—for if it miſſes a vital part on your right ſide—'twill be very hard if it don't ſucceed on the left!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: A vital part! O, my poor vitals!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: But, there—fix yourſelf ſo— [Placing him. let him ſee the broad ſide of your full front—there —now a ball or two may paſs clear thro' your body, and never do any harm at all.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Clean thro' me!—a ball or two clean thro' me!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Aye—may they—and it is much the genteeleſt attitude into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Look'ee! Sir Lucius—I'd juſt as leive be ſhot in an aukward poſture as a genteel one— ſo, by my valour! I will ſtand edge-ways

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: (Looking at his watch.) Sure they don't mean to diſappoint us.—Hah?—no faith—I think I ſee them coming.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Hey!—what!—coming!—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Aye—Who are thoſe yonder getting over the ſtile?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: There are two of them, indeed!—well— let them come—hey, Sir Lucius!—we—we—we —we—won't run.—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Run!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: No—I ſay—we won't run, by my valour!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: What the devil's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Nothing—nothing—my dear friend— my dear Sir Lucius—but—I-I-I don't feel quite ſo bold, ſomehow—as I did.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: O fie!—conſider your honour.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Aye—true—my honour—Do, Sir Lucius, hedge in a word or two every now and then about my honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well, here they're coming.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Sir Lucius—if I wa'n't with you, I ſhould almoſt think I was afraid—if my valour ſhould leave me!—Valour will come and go.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Then, pray keep it faſt, while you have it.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Sir Lucius—I doubt it is going—yes— my valour is certainly going!—it is ſneaking off!— I feel it oozing out as it were at the palms of my hands!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Your honour—your honour—Here they are.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: O mercy!—now—that I were ſafe at Clod-Hall! or could be ſhot before I was aware!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your moſt obedient—hah! —what Captain Abſolute!—So, I ſuppoſe, Sir, you are come here, juſt like myſelf—to do a kind office, firſt for your friend—then to proceed to buſineſs on your own account.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: What, Jack!—my dear Jack!—my dear friend!

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Heark'ee, Bob, Beverley's at hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Acres—I don't blame your ſaluting the gentleman civilly.—So, Mr. Beverley, (to Faulkland) if you'll chuſe your weapons, the Captain and I will meaſure the ground.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: My weapons, Sir.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Odds life! Sir Lucius, I'm not going to fight Mr. Faulkland; theſe are my particular friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: What, Sir, did not you come here to fight Mr. Acres?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Not I, upon my word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well, now, that's mighty provoking! But I hope, Mr. Faulkland, as there are three of us come on purpoſe for the game—you won't be ſo cantanckerous as to ſpoil the party by ſitting out.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: O pray, Faulkland, fight to oblige Sir Lucius.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Nay, if Mr. Acres is ſo bent on the matter.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: No, no, Mr. Faulkland—I'll bear my diſappointment like a Chriſtian—Look'ee, Sir Lucius, there's no occaſion at all for me to fight; and if it is the ſame to you, I'd as lieve let it alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Obſerve me, Mr. Acres—I muſt not be trifled with. You have certainly challenged ſomebody—and you came here to fight him— Now, if that gentleman is willing to repreſent him —I can't ſee, for my ſoul, why it isn't juſt the ſame thing.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Z—ds, Sir Lucius—I tell you, 'tis one Beverley I've challenged—a fellow, you ſee, that dare not ſhew his face! If he were here, I'd make him give up his pretenſions directly!—

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Hold, Bob—let me ſet you right—there is no ſuch man as Beverley in the caſe.—The perſon who aſſumed that name is before you; and as his pretenſions are the ſame in both characters, he is ready to ſupport them in whatever way you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well, this is lucky—Now you have an opportunity—

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: What, quarrel with my dear friend Jack Abſolute—not if he were fifty Beverleys! Z—ds! Sir Lucius, you would not have me be ſo unnatural.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Upon my conſcience, Mr. Acres, your valour has oozed away with a vengeance!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p:
Not in the leaſt! Odds Backs and Abettors! I'll be your ſecond with all my heart—and
if you ſhould get a Quietus, you may command me entirely. I'll get you a ſnug lying in the Abbey here; or pickle you, and ſend you over to Blunderbuſs-hall, or any of the kind with the greateſt pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pho! pho! you are little better than a coward.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Mind, gentlemen, he calls me a Coward; Coward was the word, by my valour!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Look'ee, Sir Lucius, 'tisn't that I mind the word Coward—Coward may be ſaid in joke.— But if you had call'd me a Poltroon, Odds Daggers and Balls!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: —I ſhould have thought you a very ill-bred man.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pho! you are beneath my notice.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Lucius, you can't have a better ſecond than my friend, Acres—He is a moſt determined dog—call'd in the country, Fighting Bob.—He generally kills a man a week; don't you, Bob?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Aye—at home!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well then, Captain, 'tis we muſt begin —ſo come out, my little counſellor, [draws his ſword. and aſk the gentleman, whether he will reſign the lady, without forcing you to proceed againſt him?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Come on then, Sir; (draws) ſince you won't let it be an amicable ſuit, here's my reply.

div.stage: [Enter Sir Anthony, David, and the Women.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Knock 'em all down, ſweet Sir Anthony, knock down my Maſter in particular— and bind his hands over to their good behaviour!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Put up, Jack, put up, or I ſhall be in a frenzy—how came you in a duel, Sir?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, that gentleman can tell you better than I; 'twas he call'd on me, and you know, Sir, I ſerve his Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Here's a pretty fellow; I catch him going to cut a man's throat, and he tells me, he ſerves his Majeſty!—Zounds! ſirrah, then how durſt you draw the King's ſword againſt one of his ſubjects?

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Sir, I tell you! That gentleman call'd me out, without explaining his reaſons.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Gad! Sir, how came you to call my ſon out, without explaining your reaſons?

sp.speaker: Sir Luc,
sp.p: Your ſon, Sir, inſulted me in a manner which my honour could not brook.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Zounds! Jack, how durſt you inſult the gentleman in a manner which his honour could not brook?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Come, come, let's have no Honour before ladies—Captain Abſolute, come here—How could you intimidate us ſo?—Here's Lydia has been terrified to death for you.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: For fear I ſhould be kill'd, or eſcape, Ma'am?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Nay, no deluſions to the paſt—Lydia is convinc'd; ſpeak child.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: With your leave, Ma'am, I muſt put in a word here—I believe I could interpret the young lady's ſilence—Now mark—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: What is it you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Come, come, Delia, we muſt be ſerious now—this is no time for trifling.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Sir; and your reproof bids me offer this gentleman my hand, and ſolicit the return of his affections.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p:
O! my little angel, ſay you ſo?—Sir Lucius —I perceive there muſt be ſome miſtake here —with regard to the affront which you affirm I have given you—I can only ſay, that it could not have been intentional.—And as you muſt be convinced,
that I ſhould not fear to ſupport a real injury —you ſhall now ſee that I am not aſhamed to atone for an inadvertency—I aſk your pardon.— But for this lady, while honour'd with her approbation, I will ſupport my claim againſt any man whatever.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Jack, and I'll ſtand by you, my Boy.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Mind, I give up all my claim—I make no pretenſions to any thing in the world—and if I can't get a wife, without fighting for her, by my Valour! I'll live a bachelor.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Captain, give me your hand—an affront handſomely acknowledged becomes an obligation —and as for the Lady—if ſhe chuſes to deny her own hand writing here—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O, he will deſolve my myſtery!—Sir Lucius, perhaps there's ſome miſtake—perhaps, I can illuminate—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pray, old gentlewoman, don't interfere, where you have no buſineſs.—Miſs Languiſh, are you my Delia, or not?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir Lucius, I am not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Sir Lucius O'Trigger—ungrateful as you are—I own the ſoft impeachment—pardon my bluſhes, I am Delia.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: You Delia—pho! pho! be eaſy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Why, thou barbarous Vandyke— thoſe letters are mine—When you are more ſenſible of my benignity—perhaps I may be brought to encourage your addreſſes.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Mrs. Malaprop, I am extremely ſenſible of your condeſcenſion; and whether you or Lucy have put this trick upon me, I am equally beholden to you.—And to ſhew you I'm not ungrateful, Captain Abſolute! ſince you have taken that lady from me, I'll give you my Delia into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
Sir Luc.
sp.p: Hah! little Valour—here, will you make your fortune?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Odds Wrinkles! No.—But give us your hand, Sir Lucius, forget and forgive; but if ever I give you a chance of pickling me again, ſay Bob Acres is a Dunce, that's all.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come, Mrs. Malaprop, don't be caſt down—you are in your bloom yet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O Sir Anthony!—men are all barbarians—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: He ſeems dejected and unhappy—not ſullen —there was ſome foundation, however, for the tale he told me—O woman! how true ſhould be your judgment, when your reſolution is ſo weak!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Julia!—how can I ſue for what I ſo little deſerve? I dare not preſume—yet Hope is the child of Penitence.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh! Faulkland, you have not been more faulty in your unkind treatment of me, than I am now in wanting inclination to reſent it. As my heart honeſtly bids me place my weakneſs to the account of love, I ſhould be ungenerous not to admit the ſame plea for your's.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Now I ſhall be bleſt indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: What's going on here?—So you have been quarrelling too, I warrant.—Come, Julia, I never interfered before; but let me have a hand in the matter at laſt.—All the faults I have ever ſeen in my friend Faulkland, ſeemed to proceed from what he calls the delicacy and warmth of his affection for you—There, marry him directly, Julia, you'll find he'll mend ſurpriſingly!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p:
Come now, I hope there is no diſſatiſfied perſon, but what is content; for as I have
been diſappointed myſelf, it will be very hard if I have not the ſatisfaction of ſeeing other people ſucceed better—

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: You are right, Sir Lucius.—So, Jack, I wiſh you joy—Mr. Faulkland the ſame.—Ladies, —come now, to ſhew you I'm neither vex'd nor angry, Odds Tabors and Pipes! I'll order the fiddles in half an hour, to the New Rooms—and I inſiſt on you all meeting me there.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Gad! Sir, I like your ſpirit; and at night we ſingle lads will drink a health to the young couples, and a huſband to Mrs. Malaprop.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Our partners are ſtolen from us, Jack— I hope to be congratulated by each other—yours for having checked in time, the errors of an illdirected Imagination, which might have betray'd an innocent heart; and mine, for having, by her gentleneſs and candour, reformed the unhappy temper of one, who by it made wretched whom he loved moſt, and tortured the heart he ought to have ador'd.

sp.speaker: Abſ.
sp.p: Well, Jack, we have both taſted the Bitters, as well as the Sweets, of Love—with this difference only, that you always prepared the bitter cup for yourſelf, while I—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Was always obliged to me for it, hey! Mr. Modeſty?—But come, no more of that— our happineſs is now as unallay'd as general.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then let us ſtudy to preſerve it ſo: and while Hope pictures to us a flattering ſcene of future Bliſs, let us deny its pencil thoſe colours which are too bright to be laſting.—When Hearts deſerving Happineſs would unite their fortune, Virtue would crown them with an unfading garland of modeſt, hurtleſs flowers; but ill-judging Paſſion will force the gaudier Roſe into the wreath, whoſe thorn offends them, when its Leaves are dropt!
